/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I always prefer getting rid of heat terminology so I like the idea.

A minor concern with this change is that this change can result in unexpected behavior if a user "swaps" the hostname using the HostnameMap parameter.

```
parameter_defaults:
  HostnameMap:
    overcloud-controller-0: overcloud-controller-2
    overcloud-controller-2: overcloud-controller-0
```

However I don't think this usage is quite popular.

Another use case is assigning the same hostname when replacing a node. However in that case we assume the old host no longer exists in the stack, there should not be a problem.

(eg. when replacing the overcloud-controller-0, with keeping the same host name)
```
parameter_defaults:
  HostnameMap:
    overcloud-controller-3: overcloud-controller-0
```

We are probably able to implement the validation to avoid such situation but I'm ok with leaving that to follow-up.

Not a -1, but honestly I would deprecate these parameters, standardize on just using --limit everywhere, instead of expanding the scope of how these work.

If we are going to expand the scope of these, then we should push forward with Brendan's patches to fix the non-inclusive language:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/819889

That patch  deprecates these parameters, so it would be my preference to go with that, and then focus on how we use --limit going forward.

> b/c otherwise external tasks just run against the UC don't they?

Yes, but some tasks 'delegate_to' overcloud nodes groups. Though we convert DeploymentServerBlacklist to limit variable for ansible, unless we update inventory to filter those nodes from those groups those external tasks won't respect --limit and fail (where a node is actually down). I also see DeploymentServerBlacklist as persistent thing across multiple commands (i.e in templates) vs --limit which is one command specific.

> this conflicts with what Brendan is trying to do in his patch

As per non-inclusive language, we can do that in Brendan's patch (irrespective of these changes), but I don't think we can deprecate/drop the THT parameter atm.

You're right, it looks like delegate_to does not respect --limit. In that case, I would have changed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/856408/ to intersect with the var play_hosts, which will be the list of hosts for the play, with --limit already applied. So you could do something like:

groups[cinder_api] | intersect(play_hosts) | first

Continuing to use the blacklist params means that users actually have to specify --limit *and* set the blacklist params if they want this to work. That is confusing, and we in fact have a warning in tripleoclient to say not do that.
Using --limit does not work with external_*_tasks. IMO,we need to support heat parameters in the foreseeable future.

> it seems to me if you pass the same value for --limit in external tasks

I'm probably missing your point here. Do you mean tasks wih delegate_to would honor -limit? I don't think that's the case[3]. We still have issues reported when doing upgrade with some broken nodes even after[1]. That's why we came up with a solution[2], may not be the best one but works.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/935c6592cdf9a324ad0775d26681bb004ed667a9  

[2] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:deploy_exclude

[3]
[stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ cat test-playbook.yaml 
---
- hosts: Undercloud
  tasks:
    - name: get hostname
      command: echo $HOSTNAME
      delegate_to: controller-0

[stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ ansible-playbook -i inventory.yaml --limit '!controller-0' test-playbook.yaml 

PLAY [Undercloud] *****************************************************************************************************************************************************************

TASK [Gathering Facts] ************************************************************************************************************************************************************
ok: [undercloud]

TASK [get /etc/hosts] *************************************************************************************************************************************************************
changed: [undercloud -> controller-0]

PLAY RECAP ************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
undercloud                 : ok=2    changed=1    unreachable=0    failed=0    skipped=0    rescued=0    ignored=0

it seems to me if you pass the same value for --limit in external tasks, the right nodes will automatically be excluded by ansible. Unless there are different inventories being used, with different node names. But if that were the case, then I suspect the blacklist wouldn't work either.

> groups[cinder_api] | intersect(play_hosts) | first

That would not work as play_hosts (hosts for the play) for external tasks is ['undercloud'] and intersection would give nothing. If we use 'difference' instead of 'intersect' it would not honor --limit.

What we instead need is a filter that parses 'ansible_limit' special variable and gives us nodes/groups that are to be excluded from delegate_to. The other option is we get rid of all delegate_to tasks.


> Continuing to use the blacklist params means that users actually have to specify >--limit *and* set the blacklist params if they want this to work


Right, that's true for 'overcloud deploy (if --limit is used for scale-out)/upgrade run and there are broken nodes that needs to be excluded, but not for 'overcloud external update/upgrade' where --limit is kind of useless atm.
Could you elaborate more on why users have to both specify --limit *and* set the blacklist params?

do you mean external tasks that call ansible-playbook themselves? b/c otherwise external tasks just run against the UC don't they?

We'd have to make them work, just like we did the blacklist parameters. The ansible_limit variable exists, which should be the value of whatever was passed for --limit. We ought to be able to use that when a call to ansible-playbook is constructed.

Otherwise, if we are going to stick with parameters, this conflicts with what Brendan is trying to do in his patch. If we aren't going to deprecate these, then we should at least fix the non-inclusive language.

I agree with Rabi point of view, that --limit and DeploymentServerBlacklist have different purpose and one cannot be replaced by the other. 

Regarding using ansible_limit variable in external_*_tasks. This seems more complicated than just using it directly in ansible tasks. If we want to stick to supporting the same limit value patterns as there are implemented in ansible call[1] we would need to do some pre-processing of whatever is passed to limit in tripleo-pythonclient and construct inventory on the fly, inmho.

[1]https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/intro_patterns.html#common-patterns

requirements.txt.message:
This is a fork, not really active, of an other library which does not exists anymore. Apparently it doesn't support IPV6. Sockets disconnections seems poorly handled [1]. The latest changes/activities dates back to April 2021.

From my view point I don't think using this library is a solution.

https://github.com/Gr1N/nats-python/pull/5

Personally I'd prefer to see if we can use nats.py [1]. This could be a good opportunity to see how we can made async coexist with eventlet, and it could help us to define guideline to see how to move Openstack away from eventlet. We could kill two birds with one stone

As nats.py [1] is the official python implementation for nats, I'm less worried about the perenity of its maintenance. I don't expect that this project would become inactive in few months.

If we isolate the development of this new driver (based on nats.py) on an development branch, by trying to make the libs (nats.py/eventlet) coexist we won't trigger lot of side effects for the other deliverables and we could softly see how-to designs guidelines to drop eventlet in the same time. 

[1] https://github.com/nats-io/nats.py

Yeah, but we need also other oslo libs to support it this way. I have little experience at this level of openstack programming. Definitely doable, but I can't guess any rough numbers how much work this really is.

We need an asyncio plan and a simple-enough PoC to kickoff this plan.

I am thinking about porting Keystone to work on asyncio, then something that utilises RPC but in a very simple manner, like Blazar.

To summarize our IRC discussion, the main problem we face by using nats.py is that that's library is based on asyncio. 

On Openstack we widely use eventlet and gevent.

The issue is that eventlet/greenlet and asyncio cannot live together inside the same application, and when you wrap a sync library with an async API, you have to decide in which world you wanna live.

While service needs to rely on eventlet we can't move libraries to asyncio. Indeed it seems it is generally impossible to have eventlet and asyncio used in the same process without stepping onto bugs.

During previous Openstack series, one of the main blocking point to move away from eventlet was oslo.db which relied on version of sqlalchemy who were not compatible with asyncio. That mean that services have to rely on gevent and eventlet to green the world. Fortunately for us the support of asyncio have been added in recent versions of sqlalchemy [1]. The good news is that we already support compatible versions in our upper-constraints [2].

Ensuring that oslo.db support well asyncio, would makes our life easier to move services (and also the other oslo libs) away to eventlet too.

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/extensions/asyncio.html
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/master/upper-constraints.txt#L150

I, personally, prefer to work on an approach that cleans up the eventlet in its entirety, however, I understand it might not be easy. I wonder if we can have oslo libs supporting *both* (but not at once!!) the event loops during the migration period. Blazar is a good example because it is relatively simple, yet relies heavily on RPC.

Just leaving these links here in case they might come useful later:
https://github.com/miguelgrinberg/greenletio
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/extensions/asyncio.html

Freeing Blazar from eventlet without relying on IPC to RPC will avoid performance issues introduced by the IPC to RPC calls. So, personally, I prefer this plan of action.

Without too digging this point, I'd say that at long we as only load the NATS driver into Blazar and at long as Blazar is free from eventlet, then the Oslo libs can support the both libs (asyncio and eventlet) in parallel. As long they are not loaded at the same time, I don't think this is an issue.

It is also interesting that the official library (excluding the JetStream support which was not there yet for the legacy lib) is already 6x bigger (though some of that factor might be contributed by the very descriptive comments). There seems to be logic to handle reconnects, server switching, undelivered messages, unreceived replies... We *must* use the up-to-date and official one.
I.e., similarly we need oslo.db and its driver to support the operations in async (otherwise we will get event loop block).

I agree with the asyncio plan and porting first something simple like blazar.

Are you thinking that we should drop eventlet from blazar? Or, are you thinking that we should rely on IPC to RPC first like suggested by Sean on IRC? (through privsep messages, or by using the socket notification driver https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.messaging/+/841892).

If you think we need to drop eventlet first, then we should identify which part of blazar needs to become async and then update its code base. Once blazar is fully  transitioned away from eventlet then we could start using  oslo.messaging' nats driver.

In this way, by starting with simple deliverables first (e.g blazar), we could migrate more and more services and then finishing with the heavy eventlet consumers like Nova.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is there any chance of getting these customizations into the primary library? If we use a custom one then we are basically committing to maintaining it indefinitely.

It looks no... I had sent merge requests to the upstream repo, but I got nothing. It is not mainteined for a few months and I've extended it too much. So, I decided to fork it as pynats2 (https://github.com/yosshy/pynats2) recently.

specs/ussuri/nats-transport.rst.message: Nits => "Streaming"

Unclear about what this means - message lifetime is dependent on use case.  Specifically RPC does not require storage but Notifications does.

Will this driver support Notifications API which requires messages be stored until receivers become available?

No. I'm not sure about Notification API, but I have 2 ideas:

* Using NATS Streaming Server[1]. It has message persistence and looks suitable for Notification API.
* Limits NATS for RPC usage. There are several drivers supporting it.

[1] https://docs.nats.io/nats-streaming-concepts/intro
i would limit it to RPC initally to reduce the scope and consier notification later.
What will be the resource savings of NATS as compared to RabbitMQ in a typical deployment?
The file size of a statically linked binary of nats-server 2.4 is ~9.5MB. Of course, it works without any other binary file.

i dont think diskspace was what ken was asking about.
disk is cheap and largely irrelevent the benifits woudl come form reduced ram or cpu load. im not sure if that is quantified in any public benchmarks or if those would be transferable to openstack or not

in theory the main advantages to NATS are HA and easy scaling where it is reported to have beeter latency and throuput then rabbit in clustered operation.

Taking a step back, a proposal to add an additional messaging transport to Oslo.Messaging based on the technical merits and success of that messaging technology outside of OpenStack sounds reasonable. With the popularity of OpenStack summit sessions detailing the challenges and dislikes of RabbitMQ, it would be expected that the availability of alternative messaging backends would be followed by broad adoption. It must be recognized, however, that there is an “institutional preference” for the use of RabbitMQ in OpenStack that (for likely good) reason will never change. 

We have learned from our experiences developing and maintaining other non-RabbitMQ drivers that the biggest barrier to adoption is in the multiple dimensions of institutional knowledge gained with the RabbitMQ server across the developer, operator and vendor spectrums (e.g. development, testing, debugging, CI, deployment, configuration, ha, monitoring, operational best practices, documentation, support, etc.). The result is that to move away from RabbitMQ has a significant switching cost that is orders of magnitude greater than the noted challenges and dislikes. Short of transformative changes to the architecture of service communication in OpenStack, there is no broadly based compelling reason to adopt an alternative messaging backend beyond experimentation. The decision to add a new driver to Oslo.Messaging should recognize and factor this into the expected outcome and return on investment of such an effort.

Thank you for your frank opinion. I should understand and consider it. 
Japanese stackers will have OpenStack OpsMeetup on Dec.10 and I'll propose discussion about it.

while i dont disagree that that is all true i dont think that is a reason to not proceed with the development of the dirver. if the driver is shown to be useful it will be adopted.

the other option i guess would be to package it in a different repo and load it via stevador rather then keep it in tree. to my knowaldge this is not how oslo generaly prefers to handel this but if the concern was maintance or adtoption that would be an alternitive.
What about deployment of intermediaries? Will this require some separate infrastructure be deployed between the two communicating parties?
NATS server is a stand-alone message broker like RabbitMQ server. It requires no additional service for clients.

I'm not sure I would say "Nothing". As I noted below, because of the nature of the pynats2 driver we would essentially be adopting it as well, which puts us on the hook for any security vulnerabilities found in it.

I suppose we could pretend it's not an Oslo deliverable, but since it's an oslo.messaging-specific fork of pynats2 and owned by the same person maintaining the o.m driver, it would be disingenuous to claim it's not our problem.
Should I write "pynats2 is a deliverable for Oslo and it may have seurity volunerabilities" here?
Sure, sounds good.
Hopefully it will be positive. It would be interesting to see a benchmark comparing Rabbit and NATS throughput with oslo.messaging, kind of like NATS has on https://nats.io/about/

oslo.messaging/tools/simulator.py said that performance of the current version of NATS driver is equivalent to RabbitMQ driver (rabbit). IMO, the reason is sending messages. As rabbit, NATS driver makes connection per sending message because making connection pool for sending has several problems:

* It's not sure that the number of message broker is only one per service.
* TLS connections in the connection pool will be broken when the service forks.

It should be better to add a hook for service forking.

Since we've created a dedicated feature branch for this work called 'feature/nats-driver' you should update this entry indicating that the development will initially be done on that branch.

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/feature/nats-driver
Yeah, this shouldn't be a problem. As of the Ussuri release OpenStack is only supporting Python 3.6+. There's no reason we would need to support Python 2 for this driver.
I see.

This is a concern. Per https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/contributor/supported-messaging-drivers.html#support we're looking for two maintainers for new drivers to avoid the situation we've run into in the past where a driver is added and then quickly abandoned by the original developer. It then falls to the oslo.messaging team to do all of the maintenance on it.

One possibility would be to implement the driver in a separate repo. Since it looks like oslo.messaging uses entrypoints to find drivers I think that should work without too much trouble even today.

Then if the driver gets wide adoption, hopefully we can find enough people interested in maintaining it to bring it into oslo.messaging itself.

I agree with Ben regarding developing the driver as an external library initially.

One thing to consider is creating a feature branch in oslo.messaging for the developers to use.

In that feature branch the developers can modify the setup.cfg and package requirements to load their nats driver from pypi.  With that they can leverage the existing testing infrastructure that comes along with the oslo.messaging repo.
Looks good.

Update: the feature branch has been created:

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/feature/nats-driver

Since this is a dedicated branch for NATS driver development you can develop the driver directly in this repo rather than as an external library.  That should ease the development work a bit.  We can revisit the external library vs in-repo decision when the development is done.

We discussed this in the virtual PTG today and decided to pursue the feature branch option for now. That should allow you to make progress on implementing and testing the driver, and once the feature branch is fully functional we can revisit this topic and decide how to proceed from there.

See https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695979/

You'll want to integrate the driver in at least one deployment tool before sending the announcement.

Folks will want to be able to deploy the new driver using tooling they are familiar with.
I see. I'll make a devstack plugin for NATS.

As Andy has pointed out, having the driver available is the relatively easy part.

The hard lesson learned is that without adoption of the new driver by the available deployment tools first it will be very hard to get significant uptake of the new driver by the community.
I see.

I think it's important to point out that this is a fork of the original client library, and unless we can get the changes there into the upstream library we are also essentially adopting this. Generally speaking, the Oslo team doesn't own any of the other client libraries for the other drivers in oslo.messaging so this is a non-trivial addition.

An interesting idea! Personally, I'd do something along the lines of `[start, start + timedelta(seconds=round(range_td.seconds / period) * period]`, where `range_td = abs(end - start)` but your method is definitely easier to follow.
Please note that for ranges shorter than the collection period, this will return an empty range (for example with start=00:00:00, end=00:01:00 and period=300, the result would be [00:00:00, 00:00:00]) but it's probably not worth rewriting this code just to handle such an edge case.

files/certmonger-haproxy-refresh.sh.message:
I'm trying to understand why this conditional is here.  Note that in the original fix - we needed to always replace the ca_path file, rather than waiting whether the cert was expired.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/785020/1/deployment/haproxy/haproxy-public-tls-certmonger.yaml

If you were presumably to do some check, it would be to see whether the cert at ca_path matches the ca cert that issued the haproxy cert.

But given that this script runs somewhat infrequently (i.e with haproxy cert renewal), I'm not sure writing a check is necessary.

But I am curious - can you explain why the above check will fail if the local ca cert has been renewed (after half its lifetime), the haproxy cert has been issued with the new ca_cert, and the old ca_cert is still valid (and trusted from the last time this script ran)?

Since when the local signer CA is renewed.
It is not automatically added to the trust store
So when openssl verify ${ca_path} fails.

It means the CA is not in the systems trust store and we can assume that we need to update the trust store with the new CA.

src/ceph_osd.py.message: this function doesn't seem to be getting Ceph config info from configs
rather than copying code from the client relation, why not use a super call?
because I want a slightly different behaviour in just 1 method.
This has been updated with the new changes from ceph client.

I think that we're not gaining anything here by copying the notify code into the charm class, we can just use `hooks.notify_radosgw`, for example, until we refactor that out as well. Given that it has different semantics than the notification event based version anyways, we'll have to re-touch it here as well when we get there

The gain is in the semantics of notifying other relations. I don't think a relation library should own the code to notify other relations i.e. It should be called from the charm. Moving it to the charm also has the advantage of using emit() (which is not present in the current patchset but I do have a local branch with emit based notification.) So that way a relation would 'emit' the event to notify other relations and actual notification be handled by the charm. (just like notify client.)
I'm not super enthusiastic about one relation triggering the events to notify others, but I'm not sure what a cleaner approach would be at the moment.
we only update the osd count report when the charm is not ready for service?
That's definitely a bug :D. Fixing it.

you are correct I didn't perform the extra step of setting the venv. I think there are a number of alternate ways to run tox in workspaces, venvs, etc. which I think make coding trickier, in this case I am a KISS approach until it stop working. If i recall the all-plugin vs all debate had to do with package (RPM,deb) vs pip3 installs?

I get the KISS approach. I'm not sure whether the conversation had to do something with (rpm,deb) vs pip3 installs [1]. But the thing is that the all-plugin environment will get removed sooner or later [2] (see gmann's comment) [3]. This patch is just making sure that things will not get broken once it will get removed.

I see three solutions:

1) I can change the patch so that we use all-site-plugins tox environment (instead of 'all' + 'venv-tempest'). Although it seems to me that using the sitepackages=on is really not good practice as the tox environment is not properly isolated from the rest of the system. 

2) We keep the patch as it is.

3) If you have some other recommendations I will follow it:). I just want to make sure that we remove the all-plugin reference.

manifests/backend/ibm_svf.pp.message: I think ibm_storwise_svc is more consistent with the driver name ?

I 100% agree that renaming drivers is irritating, but it absolutely does happen. In fact, cinder has a specific mechanism to support renaming drivers in a way that provides backward compatibility [1]. Luckily this does not involve renaming the driver config options.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/manager.py#L177

I'm afraid I opened the wrong documentation.
So the cinder documentation was updated a while ago to replace storwise svc by svf[1], then we'd better use svf here. I still hope they consider renaming the code and not renaming their product again but I don't know they really want to do that now and in the future.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/753429

I hate rebranding which has been causing multiple confusions.

I still think the old naming is better. Cinder has never renamed the driver and the parameter names. We better avoid using our own naming but follow what cinder has.

Also, the documentation and the change you are referring still mention "Storwize (Cinder) driver" instead of "Spectrum virtualize family (Cinder) driver".

storwize_svc is the older name, after rebranding, it is called as svf (spectrum virtualize family).
svf includes svc/storwize, flashsystem storages.
Driver documentation [1] and a patch [2] for your reference.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.html
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/830787
Please do not hard-code the default value. This requires us to maintain these by our own. I'd strongly recommend $::os_service_default .

updated it at all the required places.

swift/proxy/controllers/base.py.message:
I wonder if it'd be better for us to rework this block like

            node = self.primary_nodes.pop(0)
            if not self.app.error_limited(node):
                self.nodes_left -= 1
                yield node
                if self.app.error_limited(node):
                    self.nodes_left += 1
                elif self.nodes_left <= 0:
                    return

(and below, too). I think it'd fix up the accounting in that unit test so we don't feel the need to comment on it.

Side note: Do we have any unit tests that cover a node getting error limited while control's been returned to the caller? How does this interact with things like concurrent_gets, where you might have

- t0: get a node, make a request
- t1: no response; get another node, make another request
- t2: first request responds 507, so the node gets error limited

It seems like the idea of this extra error_limited(node) check is to go out an extra node when *this request* caused the node to get error limited, but we have to make that decision at t1 while the request is still in-flight...

rework - Done.

The post-hoc check of error_limited does seem wonky if the iterator is used in concurrent green threads. It is likely that often control will return to the iterator, and the node is checked, before the node has been used. There is therefore no guarantee that nodes that do become error_limited will influence nodes_left.

I don't see an easy fix for that - it probably requires an explicit call back to the iterator from the node-user to indicate that nodes_left should be incremented. I don't want to tackle that in this patch.
Ick -- you could also reset the handoff counting previously...

roles/ensure-python/tasks/main.yaml.message:
I think you might want to use `command -v` here since `which` can cause unexpected bugs in bourne shells:
https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/85250

Is the concern here that on a system with python3.6, 3.7, and 3.8 that `python3` may point to the "wrong" one? If so should we consider running this task even if python_installed_version.rc != 0 to ensure the package installed python3 is the right one too?

I think most distros use some sort of alternatives setup and installing a new package should update the alternative to point python3 at the most recently installed python3.x, but I'm not sure if that is always the case.

Yes if the system has already mutliple python, this task mount the good python to default version.
But in case of python_installed_version.rc == 0, the system install a new version and assign automatically the new version to default and it's maybe a bad idea to override that
otherwise this review add new use case to bypass installation, maybe in some case is necessary, it's maybe a good idea to add a var like "python_force_install: true" to keep actual use case ?

This is clearly something we do not want to do unless it is an opt-in option named like replace_system_python.

The outcome of this action is and almost guaranteed breakage of the system. I am worried about side effects even on basic containers.

Overall I like the idea of making ensure-python idempotent (not to anything if not needed), but that last task is really problematic.

actions.yaml.message:
This is an experiment / proof of concept that produces output like this:

```
❯ juju run-action --wait glance/0 describe-status --format=json | jq -r '.[].results.output'
              ingress-internal:    waiting | relation incomplete
                ingress-public:    waiting | relation incomplete
              identity-service:    waiting | relation incomplete
                          amqp:    waiting | relation incomplete
                      database:    waiting | relation incomplete
                         peers:     active |
                          ceph:     active |
                      workload:    unknown |
          container:glance-api:    unknown |
```

I feel like this kind of thing will be helpful for debugging in the future, especially now that we actually track all these statuses.  Probably out of scope right now though.

src/charm.py.message: self.status is set by the parent RelationHandler class in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ops-sunbeam/+/852796/19/ops_sunbeam/relation_handlers.py ; it's a compound_status.Status object.
moved
this workload status is defined in the parent charm class - the idea is to always have a 'workload' status available for the charm to reduce boilerplate.
outdated
self.status is set by the parent RelationHandler.  It will be labelled with the relation name, and part of the status pool.
Done

We have a few options currently on my experimental branch of compound-status for setting a status given a pool and a status label:

```
self.status_pool.workload.set(WaitingStatus())
self.status_pool.workload = WaitingStatus()
self.status_pool.set_status("workload", WaitingStatus())
self.status_pool.get("workload").set(WaitingStatus())
```

I feel like there are too many, but not sure yet which we should narrow it down to.

Note that the first two (attribute based) only can be used of the status label is known at edit-time.  Works here because this status is statically defined with the "workload" label.

I think I'm currently in favour of dropping the __getattr__ / __setattr__ methods, and sticking with the last two examples above.  Mainly because they have limited use cases.  I think we still need a clear way to get a Status object from the pool - for eg. if we want to pass it around as a variable.   And a pool.set_status() shortcut method will probably be widely useful.

outdated; we're using a simple implementation now, with a single way of updating a status:

```
status.set(WaitingStatus(...))
```

This has worked for all cases so far, but we may have more requirements in the future.

There's going to be some interesting overlap with statuses I reckon.  Here for example the workload is blocked on missing storage, while at the same time, the storage relation above will be in a blocked or waiting status.

If all the statuses are shown, this could actually be quite useful for quickly seeing an overview of what's going on here.  For example, the workload might be in 'blocked, missing storage...', while the storage relation might be something like 'maintenance, checking ceph storage'.

With the original idea of a priority queue of statuses, where the user will only see the "highest priority" status message.  For the example above, they will see the 'blocked, missing storage', and miss the extra context from the storage relation.  Note that this is no worse than how statuses are handled today, and it will still be neater tracking statuses from the charm's point of view.

There's going to be pros and cons of each I reckon... interesting.

I reckon a best of both worlds will be to show the highest priority status by default, but then provide a quick method of expanding to show all the statuses, and potentially related log messages.  This could have real potential to show a really neat and easy to read overview of the current state of the charm, and help with debugging.  Not sure what this kind of detailed overview will look like, or how we would implement it, but here's my thoughts anyway. :)
Done
Maintenance should only be used for long running ops.
Ack
ActiveStatus should have no message - that seems to be an agreed standard as of recent times.
Ack

# I think this status should be set in some on_something handler,
# (see comments on
# https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ops-sunbeam/+/852796 )
# but that would be kind of awkard
# considering the deep inheritance chain here... :(
#
#
# It would be convenient to track status as a single higher level
# "storage" status, or independently track ceph and local storage status,
# registering in the status pool only when actually being used.
# Probably a case where composability beats inheritance here.
# Something like this maybe:
#     class GlanceOperatorCharm:
#     ...
#       def on_something(...):
#           ...
#           if self.has_ceph_relation():
#               self.storage_relation_handler = CephClientHandler(...)
#           elif self.has_local_storage():
#               self.storage_relation_handler = LocalStorageHandler(...)
#           else:
#               self.status.set(BlockedStatus("no storage configured")
# Thoughts?
# We already have similar logic in the configure_charm method btw.
#
# Something else to consider if we did this kind of thing
# would be how to handle reconstituting the status pool state.
# We want to restore all the statuses that were previously set,
# to have an accurate summary/status,
# and this is how it currently works.
# However, then we would need to manually
# remove a status from the pool by name,
# which would be messy and error prone.
# Better would be to restore state in the status pool,
# but only actually add that state to a live status object,
# if a status with that name is registered in the code.
# But then we have the question of what if a status is only 
# registered/added in some code paths (ie. not always in init methods)?
# This could cause inconsistencies or flipflops with the status...
Done

Note on the restoring statuses potential issue: I think we have several options for managing statuses that have transitioned from being used to not any more (for example with an optional relation being removed) or being used in a different way (eg. mandatory to optional relation).

Some initial ideas:

Always ensure we define statuses and add them to the pool declaratively, as in always in code paths that will be part of every hook run (in __init__ methods, not behind conditions, etc.).

For optional/mandatory transition, we could add some conditions in the relation handler init that does something like:

  if mandatory and self.status is Unknown:
    self.status.set(Waiting)
  elif not mandatory and self.status is Waiting:
    self.status.set(Unknown)  # reset because we no longer care that the relation is missing
    
I'm not sure I'm a fan of the above though, because we're now reading from the latest set state of the status, instead of being able to just set and forget.

Not sure why unittests are failing with this:

```
2022-09-27 01:28:40.775596 | ubuntu-focal |     AttributeError: 'CharmEvents' object has no attribute 'describe_status_action'
```

This works in the live charm, and I don't see any kind of extra mocking for the test harness in similar charms that have an action...

systemd-config/source-debian/stx-tmpfile.message:
Shouldn't the packages that are creating these /var/log/ directories be cleaned up so that they don't install anything into /var/log but instead provide their own /etc/tmpfiles.d file to create the directory? 

This would keep /var/log/ clean from a ostree perspective (as we aren't supposed to be installing anything there) and also keep the package functional as it would create it's /var/log/ directory at runtime to allow the process to start correctly.

I'm ok with merging this as an intermediate step to that end goal.

Our process is to make the changes in StarlingX by patching the packages and then upstream the changes. When the change land upstream (if accepted) we drop the patches. Sounds like we need a new story to clean this up.

rally/rally-plugins/dynamic-workloads/pr.message: when provider network is already deleted in #L165, why do you release lock on non-existent object?

Locks are stored in the rally database as rows. So even if the provider network has been deleted, the lock will still be present in the rally database. The lock has to be deleted by calling the release_lock function explicitly.
You can refer to https://github.com/cloud-bulldozer/browbeat/blob/master/ansible/install/roles/rally/files/browbeat-rally/browbeat_rally/db/api.py to understand how these locks are implemented.

Had a few stable-gate fixes land recently.
Patch updated with a small custom compound-status implementation.

Something else we need to consider, but we can address this later: how to handle cases where a charm lib clobbers the status with its own message.  This is common, for example: https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-glance-k8s/src/commit/e100b8b9db998cc1240668d0da0f08376a7290cb/lib/charms/nginx_ingress_integrator/v0/ingress.py#L130

I'm thinking it won't be too much of an issue, because the status pool will be regularly re-setting the status (ie. every time a sub-status is set or added to the pool, which will be pretty much every invocation of the charm code).  But may cause confusion or flip-flopping between different statuses.
LGTM, thank you for all your work on this Samuel

So here, all child charms will now have access to a status pool (`self.status_pool`), and a default status for the main workload (`self.status_pool.workload`).

We can play with the summarizer, and whether we want unknown statuses ignored, or auto_commit.  I feel like we'll always want autocommit, but I'm not sure exactly how often the commit event from ops happens (once per hook?).

Note: worst-first results in a status like this:

```
glance/0*          active    idle        10.1.206.205         (workload:active) configuring complete; (ingress-internal:active) ready; (ingress-public:active) ready; (identity-service:active) ready; (ceph:active) local storage attached; (amqp:unknown) ; (shared-db:unknown) ; (peers:unknown)
```

import ops_sunbeam.compound_status as compound_status

I prefer to do this in charm.py as it is charm related event

I feel like if we go the route of on update_status, instead of determining status in the `__init__` methods, we'll probably still want to keep all the status logic within the class that owns the status.

Not sure what raises the ModelError - may need to set status accordingly depending how serious it is.

I'm also not sure about the ConnectionError.  I'm hoping that can be removed because of the check for `self.pebble_ready` above, and a connection error should only happen if something is really unexpectedly broken or pebble isn't ready, right?

Seems I am incorrect on ModelError, get rid of try/catch.

Also ConnectionError is not required as you already added couple of checks.

ops_sunbeam/relation_handlers.py.message: Here ensures that all relation handlers have a `self.status` in the pool, labeled with the relation name.  This means that all relations for the charm will automatically have a sub-status available, and subclasses can `self.status.set(...)` as appropriate.
Done
Here and above are some example uses for setting a status with potentially useful information.  I'm not sure if setting in this `ready` method is best.  A reviewer here may have better ideas?
Done
See comment above.

if we modelled whether the relation is mandatory or not as a constructor parameter then we can use that to conditionally make use of the Blocked status when the charm is initially deployed or when a mandatory relation is removed.

+1

Should I work on that here, or should that go in a separate patch?
Done
I think that can go here and it can default to mandatory; we have less optional than mandatory.
Sounds good.  How much will this overlap with Hemanth's work for optional relations though?

I was scratching my head as to where the status.set calls should reside - the ready method does not make a huge amount of sense to me as it might not get called whereas the _on_*** handler will get called during the various lifecycle events exposed by the underlying interface.

We only handle the ready event at the moment which in effect is the ActiveStatus.

If we all wired the other events such as 'connected' and 'goneaway' (those might not be correct names) we could use the _on_* handler for each of those to set Waiting or Blocked Status.

Ok that makes sense.  What's the purpose of the RelationHandler.ready property then?  Doesn't this then overlap with the _on_X_ready(event) method that's linked to the X.on.ready event?

If the logic overlaps, perhaps we could do something like `self.ready = True` in the _on_X_ready method?
Done
same NIT again.
Ack
Probably during construction somewhere about here - we can assess the relation status at this point in time
Done
Could you add some context to this?  What should be probably during construction here?

We'll probably want something like this as generic on all relation handlers in the init method.

We'd also need to be sure to reset the status here to Unknown if it's currently in blocked or waiting if it's not mandatory, to avoid getting stuck in a state where the handler is now optional, but it has a status left over from earlier when it may have been mandatory.

Ok I think I get it.  I'll work on it and let you know when it's ready for another look.  Thanks for your comments!

By the way, if we're always assessing status in constructors, what do you think about retaining support in compound_status for saving/loading last set statuses in stored state?  I guess it will still be useful for some cases, like in the main workload status?

Ok I have two questions:

- how to find relation status from in the relation handler?  So far I've only seen things reacting to events, so I assumed we'd need to listen for events to update the status here?

- From your logic above - do we care about the case where the relation is complete, but not ready yet?  For example, if the ingress url hasn't been received, or the database credentials haven't been set...? ie. the things we check for in the `ready` method.
Done
Note to self: "relation is complete" as used above is equivalent to handler.ready == true
I think we map these through into contexts for templates but I'm not 100% sure - I'll dig.
Ah ok if that's the case, fair enough.  We should mention that kind of thing in the docstring at least so we know why.

blocked - interface is mandatory but there are no instances of it
waiting - instance of interface exists, but it is no complete

The detail of what is missing is not important - the operator just needs to know that they either need to add a relation:

  BlockedStatus("<endpoint-name> missing")

or that we're still waiting for the interface to complete

  WaitingStatus("<endpoint-name> incomplete")
  
waiting implying that the operator does not need to take action - things should sort themselves out.
Ack
ditto comment above re messages.
Ack

I'm not a fan of "incomplete" wording - perhaps we should update this to be a little clearer?  For example "application not ready"?  Something to make it clear that the remote application is related, but the application/relation/integration just isn't ready yet (db credentials not sent yet, storage initialising, etc.).

kickstart/files/kickstart.cfg.message: You should wrap all variables in {} eg. ${PROC_SELF_FDS}.  The "$" character introduces parameter expansion, command substitution, or arithmetic expansion. The parameter name or symbol to be expanded may be enclosed in braces, which are optional but serve to protect the variable to be expanded from characters immediately following it which could be interpreted as part of the name.  Wrapping in braces is considered to be best practice in WR.  Also quoting the variable in case it is empty won't cause the script to bomb out on an error.

tripleo_common/actions/config.py.message: should we handle the PermissionDenied exception instead? Perhaps log a message, and then continue? It seems like deleting is still desired to be sure all the other files have correct umask.

We can implement our own rmtree method which can ignore PermissionDenied but, that means we can't ensure the permission of the files/directories mistal fails to deploy so is not the complete solution. Because users are not usually aware of all warnings we leave in each service logs, I think leaving the whole cleanup to users is more reliable way to let them fix the permission issue if they want.

Furthermore, the current clean up logic can wipe out the ansible.log file in /var/lib/mistral/<stack> and doesn't allow users to keep the old log file. We can implement the logic to exclude any files we want to keep but I'd prefer not implementing complicated logics at this stage considering how old stable/train is.

build-tools/stx/build-pkgs.message: not clear on what reclaim does.  please explain it better

The workflow of reuse is: first filtering all the reused packages with cache, then ask repo manager to import these reused debs into the local repo, during phase 2, there are possible that fail to import debs, then the 'reclaim mechanism' will move the failed packages back into the local build list to make sure once reuse failing, local build is the last barrier.

We allow compilation of more than one version of the same package.  
Indexing by pkg_name alone is unsafe.
Indexing by pkg_name.pkg_ver is ok.

If download fails half way it will leave a corrupted file behind. Suggest to write to FILENAME.tmp, then rename.
You are right, now the serial downloading functions are replaced by the repo manager's parallel downloading, these deprecated functions should be removed.

The latter half of my comment is more important - if you stop defining the variable for a host, it would no longer be copied into the container.

Well, the config.json changes so the config checking code should trigger the restart and avoid the stale config. I don't get the part about restarting the container when the variable is empty. I mean, if it was emptied, then it is the desired behaviour, no? What do you mean?

A long time ago COPY_ONCE was the default, but it was changed to COPY_ALWAYS:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/286671

It would be good to agree on the best approach to solve the stale config problem generally.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Just some small questions and suggestions, but overall LGTM.

doc/source/authentication.rst.message:
nit: entirely -> entire?

Just a guess, you are the native speaker ;-)

doc/source/tenants.rst.message: This sounds like one always has to configure at least one access-rule to allow (read?) access to the tenant at all. I think on the last page you mentioned that anonymous read access to any tenant is by default still possible.

zuul/web/__init__.py.message: Correct -- mostly they might want to log the user that performed a request.

Question regarding the auth parameter provided to the api methods via the decorator: The authorization is already done at this point (within the decorator). We just provide the parameter in case the api method wants to do something with the auth info, right?
Actually, since the router supplies it, if we were to remove it from here we would get a 404 since this method wouldn't match.  I don't think we need to annotate it in a comment.

The tenant_name parameter seems to be unused, but it's provided by cherrypy and needed for the `check_tenant_auth` decorator. We just don't use it directly within this method right? Should we maybe add a comment about that as this might cause some confusion? I think this applies to most of the api methods that are using the `check_tenant_auth` decorator.

It took me some time to understand the purpose of this change, although it's quite straight forward if you know :D

If I understood it correctly it's purpose is to look up the string representation of the merge mode based on it's numeric value (1-4). Which makes sense because returning the (internal) numeric value via the API doesn't make much sense.

I think it would make sense to add a short comment here with that information.

web/src/App.jsx.message:
This does feel a little -- unreacty for the want of a better term.  One thought was that we should just match on string-ends-with "auth_callback" -- but I suppose that because the login site was told to redirect back to "<getHomepageUrl>/auth_callback" it can't be anywhere else...

It makes sense that this can't be in the normal router path due to that path wanting to display lists of tenants, etc. which, as noted, may fail now.

I thought about something like setting something when we get sent to the auth-site -- but then what happens if you navigate away, etc. from the auth site and don't come back properly -- you'll have a flag set that you're currently in the auth process and not be able to get rid of it.  So this makes sense to capture the fact that you're coming back from the authentication operation.

In short I can't think of a better way!
It seems that auth_callback route in /web/src/routes.js is now redundant?  that should be removed for clarity?
Actually, I think if I stick a comment in there it will address my vague lingering concerts, so I will go ahead and squash it into this.

I thought about that and was on the fence about whether it should be removed or not (something about the router component being complete).  I'll do that in a followup so the decision can stand on its own.

I think that this part is the "main" part of this change, right? Where we actually change the workflow.

When I saw this the first time, I was wondering why we didn't handle this case via a route. Then I saw that you removed the route in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/859466/7/web/src/routes.js.

Now I'm a little confused: Couldn't we just do the "lingering" within the AuthCallbackPage itself? This part here feels a little hacky.

Having a second look I think I understand a little more :D
There is a second part, where we store the redirect property in redux, which allows us to wait for it within the AuthCallbackPage.

But then I'm confused why we even need this part here.

It's mostly about the issue in the first paragraph of the commit message.  If we try to handle this with the router, there's too much other stuff going on that's trying to update our data.  We need to leave the window.location alone until we've finished the login process, but trying to prevent the rest of the application from doing that is too complicated (perhaps impossible).

Plus, I think this actually matches the way the auth system works better.

This change is also anticipating the upcoming change to possibly require authn for read-only access.  In that change, the flow becomes:

* If the URL is auth_callback, just show that page and stop
* If we require read-only access, redirect to idp
* Otherwise, use the router to show normal content

Being able to put the redirect before normal content handling means we can ensure that we avoid rendering anything if auth is required, which I think is a straightforward and safe way of handling it.  And we must not allow control to reach the idp redirect if we're at auth_callback (otherwise we get an infinite redirect loop).

So while I can't say at this point exactly what timing issue led me to decide that this change was the one where we should move the auth_callback handling outside of the router, I think we should now consider it in the context of the upcoming change where there is a much better reason for doing so.

zuul/configloader.py.message: this seems a bit weird at first glance but model.py is ensuring this list never gets more than one entry (per the docs that it should only be set once)

zuul/model.py.message: Because all zuul configuration files are lists of items, so it's possible for any number of api-root objects to be in the file.  This data structure is used to store the raw data frome the file.  We do raise an exception if the user writes more than one, but we need to store the raw data here in order to do that.
Why do we need a list here? Wouldn't a single api_root be sufficient?
